node.title: Northern Ireland’s health minister is suing Van Morrison over Covid-19 criticism
node.alt: Van Morrison performing in London in 2020. He has been an outspoken critic of pandemic safety protocols.
node.description: The Belfast-born singer-songwriter has embraced conspiracy theories and criticized restrictions to slow the spread of the coronavirus. Last year, he released a single called “No More Lockdown.”
node.content: ["Northern Island\u2019s health minister has sued Van Morrison, who has said the minister\u2019s handling of Covid-19 restrictions was \u201cvery dangerous.\u201d", "Paul Tweed, the lawyer for the health minister, Robin Swann, confirmed on Monday that a lawsuit had been filed.", "\u201cLegal proceedings are now at an advanced stage, with an anticipated hearing date early in 2022,\u201d Mr. Tweed said in an email, adding that he could not comment \u201cany further at this stage.\u201d The Belfast Telegraph reported the lawsuit on Sunday.", "Joe Rice, a lawyer for Mr. Morrison, did not immediately respond to a request for comment on Monday. He told The Associated Press that Mr. Morrison would contest the claim, arguing \u201cthat the words used by him related to a matter of public interest and constituted fair comment.\u201d", "In June, Mr. Morrison denounced Mr. Swann from the stage at the Europa Hotel in Belfast after several other concerts were canceled because of virus restrictions.", "Mr. Morrison, 76, who was born in Belfast and was knighted in 2016, has dismissed the coronavirus pandemic \u2014 the death toll for which surpassed five million people last week \u2014 as media hype and has criticized Covid-19 restrictions though his music.", "In the fall of 2020, as another wave of the pandemic raged, Mr. Morrison released three protest songs that criticized the measures that Northern Ireland\u2019s government had taken to slow the spread of the virus. One song, \u201cNo More Lockdown,\u201d claimed that scientists were \u201cmaking up crooked facts\u201d about the virus.", "At the time, Mr. Swann called the songs \u201cdangerous\u201d in an interview with BBC Radio Ulster.", "\u201cI don\u2019t know where he gets his facts,\u201d Mr. Swann said of the songs. \u201cI know where the emotions are on this, but I will say that sort of messaging is dangerous.\u201d", "The songs also prompted Mr. Swann to write an opinion article for Rolling Stone in which he said that Mr. Morrison\u2019s \u201cwords will give great comfort to the conspiracy theorists.\u201d", "In August, Mr. Morrison dropped a legal challenge against a \u201cblanket ban\u201d on live music in licensed venues in Northern Island, according to the BBC. As Northern Ireland eased Covid-19 restrictions, live music was allowed to resume.", "Mr. Morrison welcomed the news at the time but also said he was disappointed that he had to cancel some concerts in Belfast over the summer.", "In May, Mr. Morrison, who is known for hits like \u201cBrown Eyed Girl\u201d and \u201cMoondance,\u201d released a double album, \u201cLatest Record Project, Vol. 1.\u201d The album, including the songs \u201cWhy Are You on Facebook?\u201d and \u201cThey Control the Media,\u201d has been assailed by critics who have accused Mr. Morrison of antisemitism and embracing conspiracy theories."]
